subject: Re: OT: IDEA pricing  ( was Re: [junit] Looking for some "Best Practices")
msgSnippet: ... Ah, thanks. I missed that part. ... My company pays, so the personal license isn t valid for me. But then I don t care too much, because my company pays...
messageBody:
On Tuesday, November 26, 2002, at 04:29 PM, Alain Ravet wrote:
>> So the only way the non-support contract way is better is if IntelliJ
>> didn't release any new versions during the year. Or if they did but
>> charged less for them than they are charging for the 2.6 -> 3.0
>> upgrade.
>> ..
>> .. (Though I wasn't complaining about the price; it's worth it to my
>> company.)
>
> Erik,
>
> wrong again, I'm afraid : even with the support contract, major
> upgrades
> are not free (40%/60% of full, no contract price).

Ah, thanks. I missed that part.


> Notes :
> - at their current pace, they produce about 1 major release/year.
> - last year, for Easter, and Christmas, it was possible to buy
> personal licenses for 200$. There is much hope they will keep
> this good habit.

My company pays, so the personal license isn't valid for me. But then I
don't care too much, because my company pays...


> Or $0, if you don't need/wish to upgrade.

The only thing crazier than not using IDEA (or Eclipse perhaps) is
using an old version!


Erik
